text: New York City spent at least $52 million to create a temporary facility in Queens to relieve overwhelmed hospitals. “This facility will be crucial,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said. But in the month it was open, the hospital treated only 79 virus patients. https://t.co/z2Bi8EOxIp

name: nytimes
text: Doctors wanted to transfer coronavirus patients to the field hospital built at the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, but our reporter, @brianmrosenthal, found that they were blocked by bureaucracy, turf battles and communication failures https://t.co/h5KYkGrpG0

name: nytimes
text: New York paid as much as $732 an hour for some doctors at Billie Jean King, but the city made them spend hours on paperwork. They were supposed to treat coronavirus patients, but they did not accept people with fevers, a hallmark symptom of the virus. https://t.co/z2Bi8EOxIp https://t.co/WiVsXFbjDX

name: nytimes
text: The contractor for the facility was SLSCO, a Texas company best known for helping build part of President Trump’s border wall. The final bill for the project is still being tallied; it could top $100 million. https://t.co/z2Bi8EOxIp

name: nytimes
text: Several workers at Billie Jean King said they grew increasingly frustrated to report to a sea of empty beds. Several mentioned that 3 men with mild symptoms died while quarantining at a Manhattan hotel. https://t.co/z2Bi8EOxIp https://t.co/63MC9eC4p8

name: nytimes
text: The story of the Billie Jean King facility illustrates the missteps made in the race to create more hospital space in New York. It is a cautionary tale for other states now facing surges in cases and for New Yorkers bracing for a possible second wave. https://t.co/z2Bi8EOxIp

name: nytimes
text: The facility opened on April 10, during the grimmest week of the pandemic in New York. Less than 4 miles away, the emergency department at the Queens Hospital Center was at triple capacity. https://t.co/z2Bi8EOxIp https://t.co/L1HMPARAhI
